title: 111_s1092
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reenergize America Loan Program Act of 2009" and establishes the Reenergize America Loan Program. The definitions in this section include terms like "Fund" referring to the Reenergize America Loan Program Fund, "Indian tribe" as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, "Program" for the Green America Loan Program, "Qualified person" as an individual or entity capable of meeting loan terms, "Secretary" meaning the Secretary of Energy, and "State" defined broadly. The "Reenergize America Loan Program" is established within the Department of Energy to provide zero-interest loans to qualified individuals for energy efficiency and renewable generation projects. Funds are allocated to States for this purpose. The "Reenergize America Loan Program" allows States to allocate funds for conservation plans approved under the Energy Policy and Conservation Act. States can impose administrative fees on loan recipients and retain loan repayments for additional loans under approved terms by the Secretary. The "Reenergize America Loan Program" requires States to submit a 5-year plan for fund distribution, undergo annual audits, and reapply for future allocations. The Secretary considers energy savings and renewable energy in approving and allocating funds among States. The Secretary considers energy savings, renewable energy potential, regional energy needs, and equitable fund distribution. Loans from States are limited to $5,000,000 for a maximum of 4 years. A revolving fund called the "Reenergize America Loan Program Fund" is established with Federal royalties from oil and gas. The Fund receives $1 billion annually from Federal energy leases for fiscal years 2010 through 2020, after prior distributions to States and other funds. The Fund receives $1 billion annually from Federal energy leases for fiscal years 2010 through 2020, after prior distributions to States and other funds. Expenditures from the fund include allocations to recipients under various Acts such as the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, Land and Water Conservation Fund Act, National Historic Preservation Act, and the coastal impact assistance program. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers necessary amounts from the Fund to provide allocations to States. Up to 5% of the Fund is available for administrative expenses. Transfers to the Fund are made monthly from the Treasury's general fund based on estimates. For fiscal years 2010 through 2020, the Secretary of the Treasury will use available funds from the Fund to carry out the Program, with adjustments made based on prior estimates.
